title: Although I have learned more about writing over the past six years, my writing seems to have gotten worse during this time. What happened? - Quora

response.answer_text: The more you know about a subject, the closer you get to realising how much more there is to learn. It’s similar to the phenomenon of Mount Stupid; as you start learning about a subject, you are more likely to talk to people about it. Once you reach a certain critical point of understanding, you are less and less likely to want to talk about it because you realise how much there is you don’t know — that everything you’re saying could be wrong.  In your case, it could simply be that you’ve learned so much over the last six years that you are now more able to notice the problems in your current writing. You’ve learned enough that you’re starting to realise that you still have a long way to go before you master the craft. In other words, it could just be a perceptual thing. It could also be that you now have a good idea of what ‘good’ writing entails, so you are unfairly restricting yourself in trying to keep to all those “rules” you’ve discovered. When you didn’t know those rules, you weren’t so restricted — you suffered a lot less from analysis paralysis. You might be writing about things you don’t care as much about now as you used to be. Passion is important for quality. If you write as a professional, your writing may now be stifled by harsh deadlines. Speed, quality, accuracy; in professional writing, you only ever get to pick two of those at any one time. You may have lost your author’s voice. That’s happened to me more than once. You could even have just gotten lazy with your writing, and failing to edit and proof and redraft as you should. There are 1001 different possibilities really.

It could be that in learning more about writing, you’ve gotten yourself trapped in the idea of “good” writing as very literary and grandiose and are now overwriting because of that. It happens to the best of us. I took AP English in my last year of high school, and I learned a lot more about writing through that course, but my creative writing temporarily suffered due to the fact that I’d been overexposed to stuffy, antiquated literature. There’s nothing wrong with that kind of literature, of course, but that style of writing is outdated for creative writing today. The thing about writing is that you can’t apply absolutely everything you’ve learned about it all at once - some of the advice is just bad, some of it is good, and a lot of it just contradicts other pieces of advice when you put it all together. Follow some of the rules, but don’t overthink it and follow all of them.
You ‘probably’ started thinking too much when writing which might have led to you subconsciously putting restrictions on yourself.
May be its too contrived, it has to be a spontaneous overflow of emotions,thoughts translating into words.
